questions.text: A female patient presents to you with secondary dysmenorrhea. Which of the following will not make it to your Differential diagnosis list?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CIN CIN: It is a term used to describe the condition of the cervix when a part of the full thickness of stratified squamous epithelial cells is replaced by dysplastic cells CIN occurs at the squamocolumnar junction/Transformation zone. Squamous metaplasia is a normal process and occurs in all young females. WHO CIN Description Bethesda classification Mild dysplasia CIN I Dysplastic cells seen in lower 1/3 of epithelial lining of cervix LSIL Q Moderate dysplasia CIN II Dysplastic cells seen in 2/3 of epithelial lining of cervix HSIL Q Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells seen in more than 2/3 of epithelial lining of cervix HSIL Q Carcinoma in situ Dyplastic cells seen full thickness but basement membrane is intact HSIL Q I n Invasive carcinoma : Breach of basement membrane seen. Note: LSIL = Low squamous intraepithelial lesion. HSIL = High squamous intraepithelial lesion. Factors Predisposing to CIN/Ca Cervix Human Papillomavirus infection (most important) Factors increasing the risk of sexually transmitted infections- Coitus before 18 years of age Multiple sex partners Multiparity Poor personal hygiene Poor socioeconomic status Smoking (predisposes to squamous cell CA). Immunosuppressed individuals Women on OCP or progesterone therapy for a long time, are predisposed to adenocarcinoma of the endocervix In utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES). The M/C etiological factor associated with cancer cervix is Human Papilloma Virus (HPV). High-risk HPV includes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, and 68. Low-risk HPV associated with genital warts is subtypes 6 and 11. M/C HPV subtype a/w Ca cervix is HPV-16. The HPV subtype most specific f or the Ca cervix is HPV-18. M/C HPV subtype a/w squamous cell carcinoma i s HPV-16. M/C HPV subtype a/w adenocarcinoma is HPV-18 OPTIONS B, C, and D are cause of secondary dysmenorrhea.

Extraedge:

Causes of secondary dysmenorrhea: PID Endometriosis Adenomyosis IUCD Uterine fibroid Polyps Cervical stenosis Congenital malformation of the uterus like bicornuate uterus Management: Treatment of the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of vulvar lesions that have worsened over the past 6 weeks. She has 2 sexual partners in the past year. H/O genital herpes simplex virus at 23 years. She had one sexual partner who was treated for syphilis. PAP smear shows atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance with negative high-risk HPV testing. The patient smokes cigarettes but doesn't use alcohol or illicit drugs. Examination reveals multiple small, papular growths at the vulva and over the labia majora. A few lesions are fragile and bleed on manipulation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Genital warts as PAP smear shows atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance with negative high-risk HPV testing HPV 6 and 11 are most likely to cause Genital warts whereas high-risk strains 16 and 18 are associated with intraepithelial neoplasia and cervical cancer.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Condylomata lata are flat, velvety lesions, broader base, and flatter surface, and are lobulated or plaque-like.It is seen in patients with SYPHILIS. Option C: presents as single/clustered blisters or superficial, tender ulcers, not flat or protuberant growth. Option D: caused by a poxvirus. Single or multiple small, pearly, painless nodules with central dimples or pits. They do not bleed on contact.

questions.text: During a routine busy day in the laboratory, the technician forgets to label the above figure. The following specimen came from gynecology OPD. From your knowledge of histology find from which of the following conditions was the sample taken for histology from Gynae opd?

options.label: A
options.text: Sample from endocervix for adenocarcinoma cervix

options.label: B
options.text: Sample from exocervix for cervical carcinoma

options.label: C
options.text: Sample from a newborn vaginal wall for rhabdomyosarcoma investigations

options.label: D
options.text: Sample from Urethra for urethral discharge follow up

questions.correct_answer: B. Sample from exocervix for cervical carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sample from exocervix for cervical carcinoma The histology image shows stratified squamous epithelium, out of the options only exocervix has this. Cervix has 2 different types of epithelium Exo cervix has –stratified squamous epithelium (option b) The Endo cervix has – columnar epithelium (option A) Normal colposcopic picture of the transformation zone: squamous epithelium (SE), the columnar epithelium (CE), and the squamocolumnar junction (SCJ). (Source: From Figure 137-2B. John L Pfenninger and Grant C Fowler: Pfenninger and Fowler's Procedures for Primary Care, 3rd Ed. Mosby: Elsevier, 2011.)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - Endo cervix has – columnar epithelium Option C - Vagina is lined by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, but the newborn vagina is lined by transitional epithelium Option D - Urethral sample will have transitional epithelium

questions.text: All of the following changes are seen in dysplasia of the squamocolumnar junction, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breaking of basement membrane Breaking of the basement membrane is not seen in dysplasia. Dysplasia: Represents a change in which there is an alteration in cell morphology and disorderly arrangement of the cells of the stratified squamous epithelium. It is a premalignant lesion. Characteristics of Dysplastic CELL: Vary in size, shape, and polarity. Have altered nucleo-cytoplasmic ratio (N/C ratio is increased). Have large, irregular hyperchromatic nuclei with marginal condensation of chromatin material. Have several mitotic figures. The basement membrane, however, is intact and there is no stromal infiltration. CIN: Term CIN (Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia): has almost universally replaced the WHO classification of dysplasia.

Highyeild:

CIN: It is a term used to describe the condition of the cervix when a part of the full thickness of stratified squamous epithelial cells is replaced by dysplastic cells CIN occurs at the squamocolumnar junction/Transformation zone. Q Squamous metaplasia is a normal process and occurs in all young females. WHO CIN Description Bethesda classification Mild dysplasia CIN I Dysplastic cells seen in lower 1/3 of epithelial lining of cervix LSIL Q Moderate dysplasia CIN II Dysplastic cells seen in 2/3 of epithelial lining of cervix HSIL Q Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells seen in more than 2/3 of epithelial lining of cervix HSIL Q Carcinoma in situ Dyplastic cells seen full thickness but basement membrane is intact HSIL Q I n Invasive carcinoma : Breach of basement membrane seen. Note: LSIL = Low squamous intraepithelial lesion. HSIL = High squamous intraepithelial lesion. Factors Predisposing to CIN/Ca Cervix Human Papillomavirus infection (most important) Factors increasing the risk of sexually transmitted infections- Coitus before 18 years of age Multiple sex partners Multiparity Poor personal hygiene Poor socioeconomic status Smoking (predisposes to squamous cell CA). Immunosuppressed individuals Women on OCP or progesterone therapy for a long time, are predisposed to adenocarcinoma of the endocervix In utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES). The M/C etiological factor associated with cancer cervix is Human Papilloma Virus (HPV). High-risk HPV includes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68. Low-risk HPV associated with genital warts is subtypes 6 and 11. M/C HPV subtype a/w Ca cervix is HPV-16. The HPV subtype most specific f or the Ca cervix is HPV-18. M/C HPV subtype a/w squamous cell carcinoma i s HPV-16. M/C HPV subtype a/w adenocarcinoma is HPV-18

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C, and D: see n in dysplastic cells.

questions.text: Pap smear is useful in the diagnosis of all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gonorrhea Gonorrhea is not detected on a Pap smear. Options B, C, and D - can be detected on the PAP smear. The Papanicolaou test (also called Pap smear, Pap test, cervical smear, or smear test) is a screening test to detect premalignant and malignant processes in the transformation zone.

Highyeild:

Pap Smear (Exfoliative Cytology) Time for initiating pap smear: 21 years of age regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse. The instrument used: Ayres spatula and endocervical brush Method: Ayres spatula is rotated 360° over a portion vaginalis of the cervix and 1st slide is prepared With cytobrush, 2nd slide is prepared from the endocervix Control slide prepared from posterior wall/posterior fornix of vagina Fixative used: 95% ethyl alcohol and ether.

Extraedge:

Revised Guideline for Pap Smear: Cervical Cancer Screening Age to begin pap smear = 21 years Women aged 21-29 years should have a pap test every 3 years (earlier it was done annually) Women aged 30-65 years should have a pap test and HPV testing every 5 years. It is acceptable to have a pap test alone every 3 years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years if they do not have a H/O moderate or severe dysplasia or cancer and they have had either three negative pap test results in a row or two negative co-test results in a row within 10 years, with the most recent test performed within the past 5 years. Women, who have a history of cervical cancer, are infected with HIV, or have been exposed to DES should have annual screening done. In HIV-positive females, if three consecutive tests are normal, they can have testing once in every 3 years instead of annually. Abnormal results are reported according to the Bethesda System . They include: In the Bethesda system: The most common cytological abnormality encountered is atypical squamous cells (ASC) . The category ASC is further divided into ASCUS (atypical squamous cells of unknown significance), and ASC-H (atypical squamous cells where HSIL cannot be ruled out) Squamous cell abnormalities (SIL) Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASC-US) Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LGSIL or LSIL) Atypical squamous cells cannot exclude HSIL (ASC-H) High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HGSIL or HSIL) Squamous cell carcinoma Glandular epithelial cell abnormalities– Endocervical and endometrial abnormalities can also be detected by pap smear A number of infectious processes, including yeast, candidiasis, herpes simplex virus, and trichomoniasis can also be detected however, it is not very sensitive at detecting these infections

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has a negative pap smear with + ve endocervical curettage. The next step in management will be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conization SHE has a negative pap smear along with positive endocervical curettage – it could mean endometrial cancer which has extended to the cervix or adenocarcinoma of the endocervix. To distinguish between the two – conization should be done. Colposcopy is of no use as it cannot visualize the upper part of the endocervix.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and D are not the next step .

Extraedge:

CONIZATION. Cone Biopsy/Conization It involves the removal of a cone of the cervix which includes the entire squamocolumnar junction, stroma with glands, and a considerable part of the endocervix. The tissue so obtained is divided into 12 to 16 segments and each one is blocked and sectioned separately. Procedure is done under general anaesthesia. Cone biopsy or conization is both diagnostic as well as therapeutic procedure. Indications of Cone biopsy Diagnostic Therapeutic Limits of the lesion can not be visualised with coloposcopy. Cancer in situ in young females The squamocolumnar junction is not seen at colposcopy Cancer cervix Stage 1A1 in young females Endocervical curettage is positive in HSIL Microinvasive carcinoma or adenocarcinoma in situ is suspected based on biopsy, colposcopy or cytology results Lack of correlation between cytology, biopsy and colposcopy results. Complications of Cone Biopsy Bleeding (M/C complication) Infection Cervical stenosis Incompetent os

questions.text: A pap smear of a 45 years female shows HSIL. Which of the following is the next step in management:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colposcopy directed biopsy A pap smear is only a screening test. To confirm we need to do a biopsy. In all visible lesions punch biopsy should be done In the case of invisible lesions colposcopic-directed biopsy is the gold standard. Thus in this case, since it is not mentioned growth is visible so we do a colposcopy-guided biopsy. Method The first step is to visualize the cervix under magnification. Leukoplakia must be looked for before applying acetic and otherwise it gets confused with acetowhite areas. A biopsy sample should be taken. Biopsy samples should also be taken from any rough area or raised area of the cervix. Any abnormal blood vessel pattern viz reticular blood vessels, comma-shaped blood vessels, or punctate blood vessels should be biopsied. Then 3-5% acetic acid should be applied on the cervix gently but liberally.

questions.text: The young lady comes with mild erosion of the cervix and pap smear shows dysplasia, next step is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colposcopy Erosion (ectopy): this is a condition in which the squamous covering of the vaginal aspect of the cervix is replaced by the columnar epithelium lining the endocervix. It appears as a bright red area continuous with the endocervix and with a clearly defined outer edge. It often bleeds on touch and has to be distinguished from carcinoma, tuberculosis, syphilitic and other ulcers of the cervix. “Although a cervical smear may be helpful, the distinction may not be possible except by colposcopy or biopsy”. A pap smear has already been done and it shows dysplasia which should be confirmed by colposcopy. Management of cervical erosion: If it is detected during pregnancy treatment should be deferred for at least 12 weeks postpartum. Management: – Thermal cauterization Cryosurgery Laser vaporization To destroy columnar epithelium so that on healing it is replaced by squamous epithelium.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C, and D ; are not appropriate options.

questions.text: There is an ongoing seminar on awareness about the premalignant lesion of the cervix. Which of the following will not be a risk factor for the development of CIN?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primiparity In the given question, all the other options represent a risk factor for premalignant lesions of the cervix except primiparity. Multiparity is a risk factor for CIN and carcinoma cervix.

Highyeild:

Factors Predisposing to CIN/Ca Cervix Human Papillomavirus infection (most important) Factors increasing the risk of sexually transmitted infections- Coitus before 18 years of age Multiple sex partners Multiparity Poor personal hygiene Poor socioeconomic status Smoking (predisposes to squamous cell CA). Immunosuppressed individuals Women on OCP or progesterone therapy for a long time, are predisposed to adenocarcinoma of the endocervix In utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES). Epidemiology of CIN Age CIN M/c in 20-30 years Ca in situ 30-35 years. Ca cervix Bimodal peak 1st peak seen at 35-39 years. 2nd peak seen at 55-60 years.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female undergoes a pap smear. The PAP smear appearance is given below. Which of the following features defines the cells in the given image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above. In the given question, the image shows a smear prepared by a pap smear showing dyskaryotic cells. Features of dyskaryotic cells / karyotypic cells are- Increased cell size Pleomorphism—different staining appearance Cells vary in size and shape Multinucleation Clumping of chromatin—varying degree Aneuploidy Alteration in the nuclear membrane Perinuclear halo. Hence the correct answer is option D. All of the above.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with 2 children undergoes routine pap smear testing. Her pap smear result report is given as ASC-US. what will be the next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Repeat PAP smear with HPV DNA test after 3 years as it is normal.

options.label: D
options.text: Repeat the PAP test after 6-12 months.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

HPV DNA testing. In the given question, the female is 32 years old, her PAP smear shows ASC-US i.e. atypical squamous cell of undetermined significance. In such a situation, if the female is >= 30 years of age, then she should undergo HPV DNA testing known as reflex DNA testing. HPV negative test results are followed up with a contest in 3 years in females >= 30 years of age.

Highyeild:

Management Strategies of Various Cytological Abnormalities Depending on the Report of pap smear, which is a cytological report, further inves- tigations are done: Pap smear report Next step Normal/reactive/infective Resume pap smear as per ACOG guidelines ASCUS Options are: • Repeat pap smear after 6 months • If female is >30 years, do HPV-DNA testing • If pap smear report this time is >ASCUS or if HPV-DNA testing is positive- colposcopy is done • Best method of following ASCUS is immediate colposcopy (biopsy) LSIL • Colposcopy (Gold standard) + endocervical curettage • If lesion is visible-punch biopsy Pap smear report Next step HSIL • Colposcopy (Gold standard) ± endocervical curettage • If lesion is visible-punch biopsy Definitive Diagnostic Procedures for CIN Colposcopy Cone biopsy Punch biopsy Done to confirm findings of abnormal pap smear when lesion is not visible. Done to confirm findings of colposlopy if there is a discrepency in pap smear result and colposcopy. Done to confirm findings of abnormal pap's when lesion is visible.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Colposcopy-guided biopsy is done in the case of CIN II or CIN III or in women with visible lesions on per speculum or with persistent HR HPV-DNA test results. Option C . Repeat PAP smear with HPV DNA test after 3 years should be done after ruling out HPV DNA test result. If these are normal, then we do contests after 3 years. Option D . Repeat PAP test after 6-12 months is done in the age group 21-24 years in those who have ASC-US.

Extraedge:

Classification of HPV Types Based on Cervical Cancer Risk High risk 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68, 73, 82 Probable high risk 25, 53, 56 Low risk 6, 11, 40, 42, 43, 44, 54, 61, 70, 72, 81

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a PAP smear Shows dyskaryotic cells up to 2/3 of the epithelial lining of the cervix. Colposcopy-guided biopsy was done but the complete SCJ cannot be visualized on it. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cone biopsy In the given clinical scenario, as the patient has ASC-H i.e. atypical squamous cell cannot exclude HSIL, colposcopy biopsy should follow PAP smear. If the colposcopy biopsy is inadequate, then a cone biopsy should be done to visualize the transformation zone or if the lesion is not visible completely.

Highyeild:

Cone Biopsy/Conization It involves the removal of a cone of the cervix which includes the entire squamocolumnar junction, stroma with glands, and a considerable part of the endocervix. The tissue so obtained is divided into 12 to 16 segments and each one is blocked and sectioned separately. The procedure is done under general anesthesia. Cone biopsy or conization is both a diagnostic as well as a therapeutic procedure. Indications of Cone biopsy Diagnostic Therapeutic Limits of the lesion can not be visualised with coloposcopy. Cancer in situ in young females The squamocolumnar junction is not seen at colposcopy Cancer cervix Stage 1A1 in young females Endocervical curettage is positive in HSIL Microinvasive carcinoma or adenocarcinoma in situ is suspected based on biopsy, colposcopy or cytology results Lack of correlation between cytology, biopsy and colposcopy results. Complications of Cone Biopsy Bleeding Q (M/C complication) Infection Q > Cervical stenosis Incompetent os Q

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. We do not repeat the colposcopic biopsy again as the lesion will again be not completely visible or the SCJ is not visible completely. Option B. Endocervical sampling is done in case of HSIL lesion along with a colposcopy-guided biopsy. Option D. Radical trachelectomy is done in case of early-stage of carcinoma cervix in which the tumor is < 2 cm in size.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presented to your gynae OPD for PAP smear screening and collected the report of her smear showing atypical glandular cells. What would be the next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Colposcopy-guided biopsy with endocervical curettage with endometrial sampling.

questions.correct_answer: D. Colposcopy-guided biopsy with endocervical curettage with endometrial sampling.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colposcopy-guided biopsy with endocervical curettage with endometrial sampling. In the given question, the female PAP smear report shows atypical glandular cells, hence she may also have endometrial cancer or cervical cancer. Accordingly, the initial evaluation of glandular abnormality includes colposcopy and endocervical sampling. also, for females, 35 years of age and older, endometrial sampling is also done. Hence the correct option is D.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Colposcopy-guided biopsy and endocervical curettage- alone cannot rule out endometrial involvement, hence endocervical sampling should also be done with them. Option B. Only colposcopy-guided biopsy will not be useful in case of glandular abnormalities. Option C. Cone biopsy is not indicated in this case as a first set of investigations after the PAP smear.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came to your OPD whose PAP smear and colposcopic report were labeled as CIN II. You inform her regarding the procedure you will carry out on her with the help of the following instrument given below. what is the most appropriate answer for the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

LEEP In the given clinical scenario, the patient is having CIN II, and is being treated with the help of the instrument given in the above image which are known as LEEP wires. Hence, the answer will be option C LEEP.

Highyeild:

LEEP (Loop electro excisional procedure)/LLETZ (Large loop excision of transformation zone): Currently, it is the method of choice for treating CIN II and CIN III at any age. A loop (2–3 cm) of very thin stainless-steel wire is used for excision of the TZ . Blended current (cutting and coagulation) , the low voltage output is used. It is a simple and quick procedure. It is done under local anaesthesia. Tissue up to a depth of 10 mm or more can be removed and sent for histological examination . Complications are minimal as compared to cone excision.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A and B denotes ablative procedures which can be used for CIN I especially cryosurgery. Option D. Hysterectomy in case of CIN is done only under certain indications like recurrent high-grade CIN, poor compliance for follow-up, or with associated with other gynecological abnormalities.

questions.text: You are posted in the gynae ward for 15 days during your internship. You are attending patients who will be posted for hysterectomy tomorrow morning with a diagnosis as CIN. Which of the following indication in CIN will not need a hysterectomy to be done?

options.label: A
options.text: 42-year-old female with CIN III associated with uterine prolapse who does not want to preserve her menstrual function.

options.label: B
options.text: 51-year-old female with CIN I with family completed

options.label: C
options.text: A 38-year-old female with CIN II with poor compliance for follow-up as she lives in a village far from the hospital.

options.label: D
options.text: A 44-year-old female with recurrent CIN II lesion extending into the vagina.

questions.correct_answer: B. 51-year-old female with CIN I with family completed
questions.explanation:
Solution:

51-year-old female with CIN I with family completed In the given question, indications when hysterectomy is done in case of CIN are asked basically. Hence all the options are the indication except for option B.

Highyeild:

Indication for hysterectomy in CIN lesion. Recurrent high-grade CIN lesion (elderly women) CIN extends into the vagina. Persistent dyskaryotic smear even with treatment CIN associated with other gynecologic problems such as prolapse, fibroid, pelvic inflammatory disease, or endometriosis. High-grade CGIN in elderly women Patients with CIN 3 when family completed Patients with poor compliance for follow-up.
